docs.lead_paragraph: Oregon officials reported today that in the first year of the only legally sanctioned assisted-suicide program in the world, 15 terminally ill people in the state ended their lives with lethal medication. The average age of the eight men and seven women who took their lives in 1998 was 69, the state said. Thirteen had cancer and the other two had heart or lung disease.

headline.main: OREGON REPORTING 15 DEATHS IN 1998 UNDER SUICIDE LAW

docs.abstract: Report by state of Oregon says that in 1998, first year of only legally sanctioned assisted-suicide program in nation, 15 terminally ill people ended lives with lethal medication; say that eight men and seven women took lives and that average age was 69; say that eight other people also received prescriptions for drugs to end their lives, but that six died from illnesses before taking them and that two were alive as of January 1, 1999; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Oregon officials reported today that in the first year of the only legally sanctioned assisted-suicide program in the world, 15 terminally ill people in the state ended their lives with lethal medication.     The average age of the eight men and...

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR millions of American men over age 50, the Prostate Specific Antigen blood test for detecting prostate cancer has become a routine part of their annual checkup. If they don't ask for it, their doctors often recommend it. But there are serious concerns about the test's usefulness and whether the treatment for prostate cancer may be harming more lives than it saves. Despite a recent barrage of high-profile endorsements for the test by Arnold Palmer and H. Norman Schwarzkopf, among others, not one major medical or public-health group endorses the screening. And in recent years, most of the groups that have evaluated the test either oppose its use for routine screening, or do not recommend it. These include the National Cancer Institute, the American College of Physicians, the American College of Preventive Medicine and the United States Preventive Services Task Force.

headline.main: Can the Prostate Test Be Hazardous to Your Health?

docs.abstract: Controversy over Prostate Specific Antigen blood test for detecting prostate cancer discussed; most of major medical and public health groups that have evaluated test either oppose its use for routine screening, or do not recommend it; high rate of false-positive results cited, as well as lack of evidence that early detection improves man's chance of surviving prostate cancer; graph (M)
